questions.question_text: Who should be responsible for implementing and maintaining security controls?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Data custodian

The data custodian (or system custodian) is typically responsible for the implementation, administration, and maintenance of the security controls put in place to protect the data. The data owner, on the other hand, determines what levels of security are necessary and is responsible for the overall classification and control of the data, but they don't usually handle the technical or operational tasks related to data protection.

questions.question_text: Which of the following activities would BEST contribute to promoting an organization-wide risk-aware culture?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Communicating components of risk and their acceptable levels

Promoting an organization-wide risk-aware culture involves ensuring that every employee, from top-level executives to entry-level staff, understands the nature of risks faced by the organization and the acceptable levels of those risks. By communicating components of risk and their acceptable levels, employees become better equipped to recognize and respond to potential risks in their day-to-day activities. While the other options are important for risk management, they do not directly contribute to fostering a risk-aware culture across the entire organization.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST key performance indicator (KPI) to measure the ability to deliver uninterrupted IT services?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The BEST key performance indicator (KPI) to measure the ability to deliver uninterrupted IT services is mean time between failures (MTBF).

MTBF specifically measures the average time between unexpected outages or failures. A higher MTBF indicates IT services are experiencing less unplanned interruptions in service.

In comparison:

A) Unplanned downtime only measures the duration of interruptions, not the gap between them.

Selected Answer: A
A. Mean time between failures

The "Mean time between failures" (MTBF) is a commonly used metric to measure the reliability and stability of a system or service. Specifically, it provides an average time duration between system failures. A higher MTBF indicates that a system or service is more reliable and can deliver uninterrupted services for a longer time before experiencing a failure. This makes MTBF the best KPI among the options provided to measure the ability to deliver uninterrupted IT services.

questions.question_text: An organization has engaged a third party to provide an Internet gateway encryption service that protects sensitive data uploaded to a cloud service. This is an example of risk:

comments.content: According to ISACA, it's A. Risk Transfer. Although insurance is the most common risk transfer, ISACA also says that outsourcing a process to a third party is also risk transfer.
Outsourcing is risk sharing and not transfer

discussion.content: Mitigation. Transfer works for insurance. For this case, mitigation means the customer can't run away from responsibility n accountability should the vendor caused a disruption.

Selected Answer: A
A. transfer

Engaging a third party to handle a specific security function, such as providing an Internet gateway encryption service, is a form of transferring the responsibility of managing and maintaining that function. While the organization still retains the ultimate responsibility for the risk, they've transferred the operational responsibility to the third party. Thus, this is an example of risk transfer.

Selected Answer: A
The whole concept of transferring is convoluted as the ownership of risk rests the outsourcer.

Selected Answer: A
If the organization set up their own gateway to encrypt the traffic, it would be mitigation. They are outsourcing the gateway to a third party. It is not as far reaching as say outsourcing an entire process, it seems to be sharing/transfer (ISACA uses the terms interchangeably.)

Selected Answer: C
You have to read the questions well and correctly interpret the CRISC philosophy. A risk transfer is a measure designed to reduce the loss assuming the cost of another.

Providing an encryption service in this scenario is an action aimed at reducing the risk in communication with the cloud service.

Selected Answer: C
IMO one should focus on what is the BEST answer. We know for sure that the organization is engaging in risk mitigation because they are purchasing a new security service. Legal liability for data rests with the company irrespective of oursourcing and transferring the financial consequences of loss would require a hold-harmless/indemnity agreement. The prompt does not mention that either of these risk transfer instruments are in place. Therefore the BEST answer is C. A is plausible if a hold harmless/indemnity agreement is in place but these agreements, and not the outsourcing service agreement, represent the actual transfer of the financial consequences of loss.

The ISACA materials are vague on this topic and in such cases it is best to defer to what is professionally correct.
